def solve(n, ls_xyh):

    x0 = None

    for i in range(n):

        if ls_xyh[i][2] >0: [x0, y0, h0] = ls_xyh[i]

            break

    cands = [(cx, cy, h0 + abs(cx -x0) + abs(cy - y0)) for cx in 0..100, cy 0..100]

    Then, for each (x,y,h) in ls_xyh:

        filter the candidates so that max(ch - distance, 0) == h.

    Then pick the first candidate (assuming they all agree). Return the first candidate as string. So in C, I need to implement this logic.
children.label: code_analysis

children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The filtering condition is: for each candidate (cx, cy, ch), check that max( ch - (distance between (cx,cy) and (x,y)), 0 ) == h. So for each point (x,y,h) in the input list, we need to check all candidates and keep only those that satisfy this.

def solve(n, ls_xyh):

    x0 = None

    for i in range(n):

        if ls_xyh[i][2] >0:

            [x0, y0, h0] = ls_xyh[i]

            break

    cands = [(cx, cy, h0 + abs(cx -x0) + abs(cy - y0)) for cx in 0..100, cy 0..100]

    Then, for each (x,y,h) in ls_xyh:

        filter the candidates so that max(ch - distance, 0) == h.

    Then pick the first candidate (assuming they all agree).

    Return the first candidate as string.

First, the main function:

int main() {

    // Read first input.

    int N;

    scanf("%d", &N);

    // Read N lines of x, y, h.

    struct Point {
        int x, y, h;
    };

    struct Point points[N]; // Not standard C, but assuming variable length arrays are allowed, or use malloc.

    for (int i=0; i<N; i++) {

        scanf("%d %d %d", &points[i].x, &points[i].y, &points[i].h);

    }

    // Find the first point with h>0.

    int x0, y0, h0;

    for (int i=0; i<N; i++) {

        if (points[i].h >0) {

            x0 = points[i].x;

            y0 = points[i].y;

            h0 = points[i].h;

            break;

        }

    }

    // Now find the candidate (cx, cy, ch).

    int xx, yy, hh;

    found = 0;

    for (int cx=0; cx<=100; cx++) {

        for (int cy=0; cy<=100; cy++) {

            int ch = h0 + abs(cx - x0) + abs(cy - y0);

            // Check all points.

            int valid = 1;

            for (int i=0; i<N; i++) {

                int x = points[i].x;

                int y = points[i].y;

                int h = points[i].h;

                int distance = abs(cx - x) + abs(cy - y);

                int temp = ch - distance;

                if (temp <0) temp =0;

                if (temp != h) {

                    valid =0;

                    break;

                }

            }

            if (valid) {

                xx = cx;

                yy = cy;

                hh = ch;

                found =1;

                break;

            }

        }

        if (found) break;

    }

    // Now, proceed to second step.

    // The three numbers are xx, yy, hh → cookies[0], [1], [2].

    int cookies[3] = {xx, yy, hh};

    // Compute second step.

    int leftOver = cookies[0] - cookies[2];

    int takahashi = (leftOver >0) ? leftOver : 0;

    int second_num;

    if (takahashi >0) {

        second_num = cookies[1];

    } else {

        int abs_leftOver = abs(leftOver);

        second_num = (cookies[1] - abs_leftOver) >0 ? (cookies[1] - abs_leftOver) : 0;

    }

    // Now, the output of second step is the two numbers as a string.

    // Need to create the string for third step.

    // To form the string, we can use a buffer.

    char second_output[20]; // enough for numbers up to 100 (3 digits each plus space).

    sprintf(second_output, "%d %d", takahashi, second_num);

    // Now process third step.

    // The input S is second_output.

    const char *S = second_output;

    // Count characters.

    int counts[256] = {0}; // assuming ASCII.

    int len = strlen(S);

    for (int i=0; i<len; i++) {

        counts[S[i]]++;

    }

    // Check distinct characters.

    int distinct =0;

    for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {

        if (counts[i] >0) distinct++;

    }

    if (distinct !=2) {

        printf("No\n");

        return 0;

    }

    // Check each has count 2.

    int valid =1;

    for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {

        if (counts[i] !=0 && counts[i] !=2) {

            valid =0;

            break;

        }

    }

    if (valid) {

        printf("Yes\n");

    } else {

        printf("No\n");

    }

    return 0;

}
